Checkout.js supports Checkout.com's full suite of alternative payment solutions, which is listed [here](doc:alternative-payment-methods). To offer alternative payments through Checkout.js, follow the steps below: ### <span class="step_hl">Step 1:</span> Create a payment token on your server ### <span class="step_hl">Step 2:</span> Include Checkout.js in your webpage ### <span class="step_hl">Step 3:</span> Verify the payment token to obtain the full charge response ### <span class="step_hl">Step 4:</span> Confirm payment via webhooks 
 
Not familiar with payment tokens? We recommend taking a look at our API reference before proceeding. 
A payment token is a key that uniquely identifies a charge's payment details on our payment gateway. It securely isolates the transaction value and currency of a payment and cannot be changed at the browser-end by the customer. When creating the payment token, the merchant can specify the success and fail redirect URLs using the parameters `successUrl` and `failUrl`. If the parameters are not defined, the redirect URLs fallback to those set in The Hub. ### Example request 
cURL
rename · delete
10
 
1
curl https://sandbox.checkout.com/api2/v2/tokens/payment
2
-H "Authorization: sk_test_55aedccc-7f53-4ccc-b0a6-d943decc3c31"
3
-H "Content-Type: application/json"
4
-X POST
5
-d  '{
6
    "value": 100,
7
    "currency": "GBP",
8
    "successUrl": "http://mycustomerurl.com/order?result=pass",
9
    "failUrl": "http://mycustomerurl.com/order?result=fail"
10
}'

{
2

3

Import from Gist
 
 
Set `data-payment-mode` to `mixed` to offer credit/debit cards and alternative payments, or to `localpayment` to offer alternative payments only. 
### Example: windowCKOConfig window.CKOConfig should be configured before referencing the Checkout.js <script> tag. 
JavaScript
rename · delete
17
 
1
<form class="payment-form" method="POST" action="https://merchant.com/successUrl">
2
  <script>
3
    window.CKOConfig = {
4
      publicKey: 'pk_test_6ff46046-30af-41d9-bf58-929022d2cd14',
5
      paymentToken: 'pay_tok_SPECIMENT-000',
6
      customerEmail: 'user@email.com',
7
      paymentMode: 'mixed' || 'localpayments',
8
      value: 1000,
9
      currency: 'GBP',
10
      lpCharged: function(event){
11
        console.log(event);
12
        // do work
13
      }
14
    };
15
  </script>
16
  <script async src="https://cdn.checkout.com/sandbox/js/checkout.js"></script>
17
</form>
Import from Gist
### Example: data-key attributes 
JavaScript
rename · delete
11
 
1
<!-- Configuration via data-key attributes -->
2
<form method="POST" action="https://merchant.com/successUrl">
3
  <script id="cko_script_tag" src="https://cdn.checkout.com/sandbox/js/checkout.js"
4
    data-public-key="pk_test_6ff46046-30af-41d9-bf58-929022d2cd14"
5
    data-payment-token="pay_tok_SPECIMEN-000"
6
    data-customer-email="customer@email.com"
7
    data-value="100"
8
    data-currency="USD"
9
    data-payment-mode="mixed" || "localpayment" >
10
  </script>
11
</form>

### Handlers Checkout.js dispatches events which can be handled for various purposes. The most important event in the alternative payments flow is `Checkout.Events.LP_CHARGED`, which is triggered before a customer is automatically redirected to the chosen Alternative Payment website and, if handled, will stop the flow. The arguments for this event are `redirectUrl` and `lpName` (alternative payment provider). You can then choose at which stage of the payment process you want to redirect your customer using the `redirectUrl` provided. Using Javascript, you can add a handler for the `Checkout.Events.LP_CHARGED` event as follows: #### Example: Option 1 
JavaScript
rename · delete
 
1
window.CKOConfig = {
2
  // ... other settings
3
  lpCharged: function (event){
4
    document.getElementById('cko-cc-redirectUrl').value = event.data.redirectUrl;
5
    document.getElementById('cko-cc-lpName').value = event.data.lpName;
6
    jQuery('#place_order').trigger('submit');
7
    event.preventDefault();
8
  }
9
};
Import from Gist
#### Example: Option 2 
JavaScript
rename · delete
 
1
Checkout.addEventHandler(Checkout.Events.LP_CHARGED, handler);
Import from Gist
More information on event handlers can be found [here](doc:checkoutjs-reference#section-handlers). 
 
Please send your desired `payment successful` and `payment unsuccessful` redirect URLs to our integration team to configure. 
Once payment is completed on the alternative payment gateway, the shopper will be redirected to your website. At your server end, you can obtain the payment token via the form variable `cko-payment-token`. Please refer to our Server API Reference for detailed information on how to use `cko-payment-token` to verify a payment token. The reference includes full code samples on various platforms. You can use one of our API libraries on a platform of your choice. Upon successful verification of the payment token, you will receive a request response containing the chargeId.  
 
Webhooks are the only way to confirm the successful completion of an alternative payment transaction. 
Checkout's Gateway API uses webhooks to push information to a merchant's destination URL whenever the status of a transaction changes (e.g. charge authorised, charge captured). All the notifications are delivered via an HTTP POST request in JSON or XML format. Receiving a `charge.captured` notification via webhooks is the only way to confirm whether an alternative payment charge has been completed successfully. All orders should be marked as pending until you receive a successful webhook response (response code `10000`). Only then should a transaction be marked as completed. Contact your relationship manager or our integration team to manage webhooks. More detailed information regarding webhooks is also available [here](doc:broadcast-webhooks).
